title: 113_s1799
content: The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" amends the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 to extend funding for fiscal years 2014-2018. It also includes provisions for accountability in grants awarded under the Act. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" includes accountability provisions such as mandatory audits by the Inspector General of the Department of Justice to prevent misuse of grant funds. Recipients with unresolved audit findings may face mandatory exclusion from receiving grant funds. The "Victims of Child Abuse Act Reauthorization Act of 2013" includes accountability provisions for grant recipients. Those with unresolved audit findings may be excluded from receiving grant funds for 2 fiscal years. Priority is given to entities without unresolved audit findings in the past 3 fiscal years when awarding grants. If an entity improperly receives grant funds during the exclusion period, the funds must be reimbursed to the Treasury. The Administrator may seek repayment from grant recipients erroneously awarded funds. Nonprofit organizations must not hold money in offshore accounts to avoid taxes. Nonprofit organizations awarded grants must disclose their compensation processes, including independent review and comparability data. The Administrator can make this information available for public inspection. No Department of Justice funds can be used for conference expenditures. The Department of Justice funds cannot be used for conference expenditures exceeding $20,000 without prior written approval. Approval must include a cost estimate for all conference expenses. The Department of Justice requires prior approval for conference expenditures over $20,000, including detailed cost estimates. The Deputy Attorney General must report all approved conference expenses annually to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees. Additionally, the Crime Victims Fund allocation is limited to services benefiting crime victims by the United States Attorneys Offices and the FBI. The Crime Victims Fund allocation is limited to services benefiting crime victims in the Federal criminal justice system through victim coordinators, victims' specialists, and advocates, including a Victim Notification System. Amounts made available cannot be used for any other purposes.
